posts.author: alessiaccio
posts.content:
Hi guys!
I'm beating NWN single player for the first time, but the character building is really complex for me, 'cause i'm new to the D&D mechanics. I want to beat the game with an Elf rogue with some bard levels, i like the jack of all trades characters, can anyone suggest me a good build?
Very thanks!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I usually choose either Rogue or Bard because the two classes have a lot of overlap. They both have Tumble and UMD and they both are 3/4 AB classes. Also, since neither of those classes are the favored class for an Elf, you would either have to keep the classes even with each other, or suffer a 20% experience point penalty.

Also, what modules and campaigns are you playing? I recommend the OC followed by Mines of Twin Summits to get all the way to level 40, and then starting over in SoU, HotU, and Sands of Fate to once again reach level 40, and finally, the Aielund Saga to go from level 1 to level 36. There are plenty of other things to play after that, but these will keep you busy for a while.

Ah, so no Blind Fight, Expertise, Luck of Heroes, Curse Song or Lingering Song either...

The lack of those latter two would make me lean more towards Rogue than Bard. And if you want to play an elf and avoid an xp penalty, you might want to think about Wizard - a class about which I know nothing.

I don't know if you've had the chance to read Hip's Original Campaign 2002 Revisited thread in the Modules forum, but it might be informative. Interestingly enough, when Hip himself did a playthrough he did it as a Wizard 16/ Rogue 2 (albeit as a gnome rather than an elf), with - guess what - a pixie familiar! He also relied heavily on trapping, which you may or may not fancy trying your hand at. I seem to recall playing it through as a Monk 16/ Rogue 2 human - as much as for all the free stuff Monk attracts as anything.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Hm, I seem to recall that Adam's Miller campaign only requires the base game without the expansions, it was in "hall of fame" for many years, about equal length with the OC and comes in a nice executable format, one-click away from playing it.

Adam Miller's Campaign => https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... -campaigns

Now for your rogue, I recommend a (rogue 16/ fighter 4) dexterity-based but with 14 starting strength so that you can carry lots of stuff and add some damage to your bow. Plenty of composite ones for taking...Add crippling strike, point blank shot, rapid shot, weapon specialization & 8d6 worthy of sneak attacks along with some nice elemental arrows and you can punch holes in them in no time. Use darkness scrolls so you can deliver your sneaks easily and traps to soften up bosses. Because of the rule of four, this build will end up with 16 bab, letting you shred your opponents with as many as six shots per round. Persuade will lead you to better rewards throughout the game and listen will let you perceive what's happening behind walls.

Have fun!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Just spit-balling here, but what about something like a sneaky halfling Monk 11 or 12/ Rogue 6 or 7? Monk 12 gives you undispellable Spell Resistance of 22, whereas Rogue 7 gives you +1d6 sneak attack - so, your call as to what you'd prefer.

You could start with stats of STR 12, DEX 18 (rising to 22), CON 14, WIS 10, INT 14, CHA 8.

Feat-wise, I'd be tempted to dual-wield kamas - even with the weapon size penalty for halflings - and take Dodge, Weapon Finesse, Weapon Focus (kama), 2-W Fighting, Ambidexterity, Imp 2-W Fighting, and Imp Critical (kama). Not necessarily in that order.

Might it hold some interest?

EDIT: Ninja'd by Valerfor again! Who makes an excellent suggestion

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I've been having a little think, and I wonder - with the build I posit above - whether it might even be worth going Monk 12/ Rogue 2/ Fighter 4? That would give an xp penalty, but would bring 3 bonus feats, one of which would be WS. It would mean you could also take Mobility, which might mitigate the loss of Tumble a little bit. The final one could be used for Exotic Weapons, where kukri rears its head, but you'd lose the Monk APR schedule, so probably isn't worth it. But it does leave some shuffle room. On the downside, your sneak attack would suffer, as would your number of skill points.

Just musings...

EDIT: Sorry, meant to mention, it also bumps the BAB by +1, though it's left at a still less than radiant 14. That's where the Monk attack schedule tries to help. Valerfor tries to sneak a BAB of 16 into his idea, but it's a chimera (no offence meant, Valerfor), because we all know the OC ends at level 18, not 20, so that's also a 14 in reality (you know what I mean). Nonetheless, if you want a non-melee Rogue, it's still an excellent suggestion.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I recommend that you get the full game, probably the new EE version from Beamdog. Both SoU and HotU are generally regarded as better than the OC, and they are required for most of the user-made content, much of which is also better then the OC. There is such a huge amount of excellent user-made content, with more still being made now, that it is a great bargain. It will keep you entertained for years. Also, if you ever want to play in a persistent world server (I never have), I doubt that there are any that don't require the expansions.
I got the Platinum Edition when it was the latest version. It has both expansions and some premium modules, but not as many as Diamond Edition, so I don't know how to build for the OC only, without the other classes, feats, and skills.

posts.content: oh, and with all the expansions and the prestige classes available there is a good way to mix rogue and bard or it is in every case a bad multiclass option?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The main reason to add a little bit of either Rogue or Bard is for Tumble. If you have a lot of one and a little bit of the other, that second one is not adding much. I could make a pretty good build with a medium amount of both.
How about a Dwarf Rogue 16 / Fighter 8 / Bard 16? (I chose Dwarf because Fighter is the favored class, so you would have no experience penalty as long as you keep Rogue and Bard even.
Another option would be a Human or Halfling Rogue 16 / Bard 16 / CoT 8. Actually, an Elf would be possible without experience penalty if you keep Rogue and Bard even. Using CoT instead of Fighter would cost you the Fighter 1 feat and you couldn't take Weapon Specialization and its epic follow-up.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Champion of Torm is an amazing prestige class for something like that. It will give you more BAB and will boost your saving throws, while it also has a synergy with the "charisma" aspect of the Bards. For example (Bard 17/ Rogue 13/ CoT 10) will give you so much stuff, you won't know what to do with them. If you take human as your race, you will also have zero exp-penalty for that build. If you want to play something more sinister, then both Bard and Rogue synergize incredibly well with Blackguards too. Lot's of possibilities with the expansions added, literally hundreds of builds open to you.

That being said, the base game will still offer you a ton of gameplay hours and Adam Miller's campaign will still run on vanilla Neverwinter Nights.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
It all really depends on how you want to play - and believe me, that will vary, sometimes wildly, once the game truly grabs you. And it will. You have the advantage of having played NwN in its initial incarnation, so can better grasp its fundamental mechanics, and so appreciate more what SoU/ HotU brings to the table - not so much in terms of storyline or adventuring, more what different classes, feats and skills can do for you.

I'm only 3 and a half years in, and I hope I learn something every day here (gods, I can see the firing squad lining up). There are amazing people in this Guild - even the evil ones - who will never let you sink when you have a problem, or fail to cheer when you succeed.

As to your specifics: I haven't a clue, other than wondering about the amount of replication that might go on between Bard, Shadow Dancer and Rogue. Apart from anything else, your AB would take a bit of a kicking - a max BAB of 15 pre-epic, so fewer potential hits per round (you need a BAB of 16 before you get 4 attacks per round). The prestige classes (except I can't remember PDK) with full BAB are CoT/ WM/ DwD/ AA/ BG, and everything I've learned so far is that you've got to hit your enemy to make it die. Of course, there are magical means of getting your AB up, but I refer you to my first sentence.

So, how do you like to play?

Cheers
